Introduction 

Infantile hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors composed of proliferating endothelial cells.  The lesions classically appear during the first weeks of life, grow rapidly during infancy, and regress in early childhood.

Pathogenesis



Infantile hemangiomas, the most common vascular tumors in children, are formed from endothelial cells undergoing rapid mitosis.  Natural tumor progression begins with a proliferative phase during infancy followed by an involution phase during childhood.



During the proliferative phase, benign tumor growth is related to the de novo production of a densely packed capillary network (ie, vasculogenesis) and/or the sprouting of new capillaries from existing ones (ie, angiogenesis).  This process is facilitated by angiogenic factors such as vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).  The involution phase is predominated by apoptosis as the endothelial cells are replaced by fibrotic and adipose tissue.

Clinical presentation



Infantile hemangiomas usually present between age 2 weeks to 6 months, the period characterized by the most rapid growth; the tumor is classically absent at birth but may appear as a telangiectasia precursor lesion.  Hemangiomas can arise anywhere within the body (ie, skin, mucus membranes, viscera) but usually occur as a single cutaneous lesion on the head or neck.



Cutaneous findings vary based on the depth and morphology of the lesions:



  • Superficial hemangiomas are the most common type and manifest as nontender, bright red, sharply demarcated nodules/plaques (
    image 1
    ), (
    image 2
    ).
  • Deep hemangiomas develop in the subcutaneous tissue and often appear as raised skin-colored nodules with a faint bluish hue; there may be a superficial component to deep hemangiomas. 
  • Segmental hemangiomas may have deep and superficial components, but rather than a round or discrete shape, these lesions are geographic in appearance and located over a broad distribution (
    image 3
    ).


Until age 1, lesions may continue to proliferate, increasing in size at a slower rate than in early infancy.

Evaluation and diagnosis



Infantile hemangioma is diagnosed clinically based on characteristic findings (eg, bright red, sharply demarcated nodule/plaque).  Biopsy is rarely required for diagnosis but would show lobules of densely packed capillaries lined by plump endothelial cells in the dermis and superficial subcutaneous tissue (

image 4
).



Imaging for deeper lesions or associated anomalies is typically indicated for the following:



  • â‰¥5 cutaneous lesions or segmental abdominal hemangioma:  Liver ultrasound should be performed due to the association between these lesions and multifocal hepatic hemangiomas (rare), which can be asymptomatic or associated with large vessel shunts.
  • Facial/scalp segmental lesions:  Echocardiography and head MRI are indicated due to increased risk of PHACE syndrome (posterior fossa malformations, hemangiomas, arterial abnormalities, cardiac anomalies, eye anomalies, sternal clefts). 
  • Cervicofacial lesions in a "beard" distribution:  Laryngoscopy should be performed to evaluate for airway obstruction due to deep hemangioma growth.
  • Midline lumbosacral lesions:  Spinal ultrasound is used to determine spinal cord involvement, such as in spinal dysraphism (
    figure 1
    ).

Differential diagnosis



  • Pyogenic granuloma (
    image 5
    ):  Patients present with a small, red, dome-shaped papule that commonly bleeds.  These lesions usually develop in school-aged children or adults and have an initial proliferative phase but rarely involute.
  • Cherry hemangioma (
    image 6
    ):  Lesions are small (<0.5 cm), bright red macules/papules that increase in number as the patient ages and remain stable in size.  They are the most common benign vascular proliferations in adults and are rarely seen in infants.
  • Nevus flammeus (port-wine stain) (
    figure 2
    ):  This capillary malformation begins as a flat, unilateral pink/red patch that grows proportionally with the child and may evolve into a deep purple, thickened, nodular lesion in adulthood.  Lesions are present from birth and do not regress.
  • Nevus simplex:  These flat, pink, blanching vascular lesions commonly occur on the eyelids, glabella, and nape of the neck.  They are present at birth, lack a proliferative phase, and usually fade by age 1-2.
  • Arteriovenous malformations:  Blood flows directly from arterial to venous circulation without an intervening capillary bed.  They appear as purple-red patches with visible veins and are often warm with a palpable thrill or audible bruit.

Complications



Hemangiomas are usually uncomplicated with no sequelae, but complications can occur and are usually related to size and/or location.

Ulceration 



Ulceration is the most common complication of infantile hemangiomas and tends to occur with lesions in areas subject to friction and maceration, such as in the genital region.  Bleeding may be an associated finding but is rare and generally mild.

Functional impairment or disfigurement



Periorbital hemangioma growth can impair visual development, increasing the risk for astigmatism and strabismus.



Hemangiomas involving the ear or nose can damage underlying cartilage and distort tissue shape, causing cosmetic disfigurement (

image 7
).

Life-threatening complications



Subglottic hemangiomas can lead to airway obstruction, which may manifest with stridor and hoarseness and progress to respiratory failure.  These tumors may occur in the absence of cutaneous lesions, but cervicofacial hemangiomas in a "beard" distribution are an associated finding.



Multifocal hepatic hemangiomas may have arteriovenous connections and can sometimes cause high output heart failure due to hemodynamically significant left-to-right extracardiac shunting.  Venous return to the right atrium is increased and leads to pulmonary overcirculation with tachypnea, poor feeding, and poor weight gain.  The presence of â‰¥5 cutaneous lesions or segmental abdominal hemangioma is an associated finding.

Management and prognosis



Due to the natural history of spontaneous involution after age 12 months, management of simple hemangiomas (eg, size <2 cm, location on trunk or extremities) is reassurance and serial observation.  The tumor softens, dulls in color, and can completely involute (

image 8
); however, most lesions result in a small residual area of fibrotic or fatty tissue (eg, faintly pigmented or atrophic scar).



First-line therapy for hemangiomas in the proliferative phase that are at risk for complications is topical or oral beta-blockers (eg, propranolol), which inhibit growth factors and induce local vasoconstriction to promote lesion regression.  High-risk features include:



  • Large (>2 cm), facial, segmental, and/or rapidly growing due to risk for ulceration/scarring.
  • Periorbital location due to risk for visual impairment.
  • Hepatic location (multifocal) due to risk of high-output heart failure.
  • Subglottic location due to risk for airway obstruction.

Summary



Infantile hemangioma (

) is a common, benign vascular tumor that classically presents soon after birth as a bright red, raised, sharply demarcated plaque.  The natural course of hemangiomas is proliferation in infancy followed by regression in early childhood.  Management of uncomplicated hemangiomas is serial observation.  Beta-blocker therapy should be given for lesions at increased risk of functional impairment or ulceration/scarring.
